The ResearchSpace project is supported by the Andrew W. Mellon foundation and is developing a system to bring together Semantic data, collaboration and research tools. As a result of mapping BM data to the CIDOC-CRM schema for ResearchSpace, we have been able to create this linked data and SPARQL interface.</str></arr><str name="dc.identifier">bm-sparql</str><arr name="dc.source"><str>http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/features/shakespeares-restless-world/</str></arr><arr name="dc.subject"><str>Shakespeare</str></arr><arr name="dc.title"><str>Shakespeare's Restless World</str></arr><arr name="dc.type"><str>Text</str><str>Podcast</str></arr></doc><doc><arr name="dc.creator"><str>Open Knowledge Foundation</str></arr><arr name="dc.description"><str>Open Shakespeare combines literary criticism and the internet to produce a set of tools for appreciating the national poet. Everything on the website is open, free to use, reuse, and redistribute, and subject only, at most, to the requirement to attribute and share-alike. Open Shakespeare provides:<br/>  <ul>  <li>Multiple editions of Shakespeare's plays.</li>  <li>Short Introductions, and critical essay on Shakespeare's works.</li>  <li>Tools for annotating, comparing, searching, and analysing texts whose code will be open, and encourage reusability in line with the Four Principles of Open Knowledge Development.</li>  </ul>  </str></arr><str name="dc.identifier">open-ss</str><arr name="dc.source"><str>http://openshakespeare.org/</str></arr><arr name="dc.subject"><str>Shakespeare play annotation</str></arr><arr name="dc.title"><str>Open Shakespeare - The Marriage of Text and Technology</str></arr><arr name="dc.type"><str>HTML</str></arr><arr name="ww.license"><str>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/</str></arr><arr name="ww.rights"><str>All content and data is available under a CC Attribution License (CC BY 2.5).</str></arr><arr name="ww.search_url"><str>http://openshakespeare.org/search</str></arr></doc><doc><arr name="dc.description"><str>Harvested wikipedia linked data</str></arr><str name="dc.identifier">dbpedia</str><arr name="dc.source"><str>http://lookup.dbpedia.org/api/search.asmx/KeywordSearch?QueryString=shakespeare</str></arr><arr name="dc.title"><str>DBpedia</str></arr><arr name="ww.sparql_url"><str>http://dbpedia.org/sparql</str></arr></doc><doc><arr name="dc.contributor"><str>National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH)</str><str>Joint Information Systems Committee (JISC)</str></arr><arr name="dc.creator"><str>The Shakespeare Quartos Archive</str></arr><arr name="dc.description"><str>The Shakespeare Quartos Archive is a digital collection of pre-1642 editions of William Shakespeare's plays. A cross-Atlantic collaboration has also produced an interactive interface for the detailed study of these geographically distant quartos, with full functionality for all thirty-two quarto copies of Hamlet held by participating institutions. </str></arr><str name="dc.identifier">shakes-quartos</str><arr name="dc.source"><str>http://quartos.org/main.php</str></arr><arr name="dc.subject"><str>Hamlet</str><str>quartos</str></arr><arr name="dc.title"><str>The Shakespeare Quartos Archive</str></arr><arr name="dc.type"><str>TEI</str><str>HTML</str></arr><arr name="ww.apidoc"><str>http://quartos.org/info/using.html</str><str>http://quartos.org/info/documentation.html</str></arr><arr name="ww.license"><str>http://quartos.org/info/termsofuse.html</str></arr><arr name="ww.rights"><str>Content (content being images, transcriptions, programs and scripts) of this website that has been created, and is operated by the Shakespeare Quartos Archive, is available for use by anyone under the following Creative Commons Attribution-Non-Commercial licenses:<br/>  - Attribution-Non-Commercial 2.0 UK for all content provided by institutions in the United Kingdom;<br/>  - Attribution-Noncommercial 3.0 United States for all content provided by institutions in the United States.</str></arr><arr name="ww.search_url"><str>http://quartos.org/main.php</str></arr></doc><doc><arr name="dc.description"><str>TEI-encoded commentary on Renaissance texts.</str></arr><str name="dc.identifier">perseus-tei</str><arr name="dc.source"><str>http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/collection?collection=Perseus%3Acollection%3AShakespeare</str></arr><arr name="dc.subject"><str>Renaissance resources</str></arr><arr name="dc.title"><str>Perseus</str></arr><arr name="dc.type"><str>TEI</str><str>RDF</str></arr></doc></result><lst name="facet_counts"><lst name="facet_queries"/><lst name="facet_fields"><lst name="dc.type"><int name="Images">12</int><int name="Text">12</int><int name="HTML">6</int><int name="Objects">6</int><int name="Video">4</int><int name="XML">4</int><int name="TEI">3</int><int name="Audio">2</int><int name="PDF">2</int><int name="RDF">2</int><int name="Cold Fusion metadata">1</int><int name="Concordance">1</int><int name="Data visualisation">1</int><int name="JSON">1</int><int name="Music">1</int><int name="NTriples">1</int><int name="Podcast">1</int><int name="Turtle">1</int><int name="images">1</int></lst></lst><lst name="facet_dates"/><lst name="facet_ranges"/></lst> </response>
